title: DSM-5 Criteria for Binge Eating Disorder
description: Diagnostic criteria for binge eating disorder (BED) based on DSM-5. Evaluates presence of binge eating episodes, associated features, distress, frequency/duration, and exclusion criteria.

parameters.name: binge_eating_episodes
parameters.description: Recurrent episodes of binge eating characterized by eating unusually large amounts of food while experiencing a feeling of loss of control

parameters.name: eating_rapidly
parameters.description: Eating much more rapidly than normal during binge episodes

parameters.name: eating_until_uncomfortably_full
parameters.description: Eating until feeling uncomfortably full during binge episodes

parameters.name: eating_when_not_hungry
parameters.description: Eating large amounts when not feeling physically hungry

parameters.name: eating_alone_embarrassment
parameters.description: Eating alone due to embarrassment about how much one is eating

parameters.name: negative_feelings_after
parameters.description: Feeling disgusted, depressed, or very guilty afterward

parameters.name: marked_distress
parameters.description: Marked distress regarding binge eating is present

parameters.name: frequency_duration
parameters.description: Binge eating occurs, on average, at least once a week for 3 months

parameters.name: no_compensatory_behaviors
parameters.description: Binge eating is NOT associated with recurrent use of inappropriate compensatory behavior (e.g., purging)

parameters.name: not_during_other_disorders
parameters.description: Does NOT occur exclusively during anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, or avoidant/restrictive food intake disorder

parameters.name: weekly_frequency
parameters.description: Average frequency of binge eating episodes per week (for severity assessment)

result.name: dsm5_bed_diagnosis
result.description: DSM-5 Binge Eating Disorder diagnostic result

ranges.interpretation: The individual does not meet the diagnostic criteria for Binge Eating Disorder according to DSM-5. Consider other eating disorders or refer for comprehensive evaluation if clinical concerns persist.

Meets DSM-5 criteria for Binge Eating Disorder, Mild severity (1-3 episodes per week). Treatment recommendations include psychotherapy, nutritional counseling, and consideration of medication if indicated.

Meets DSM-5 criteria for Binge Eating Disorder, Moderate severity (4-7 episodes per week). Intensive treatment recommended including specialized eating disorder therapy and comprehensive medical evaluation.
Meets DSM-5 criteria for Binge Eating Disorder, Severe severity (8-13 episodes per week). Urgent referral to specialized eating disorder treatment program with intensive therapeutic intervention.

Meets DSM-5 criteria for Binge Eating Disorder, Extreme severity (14+ episodes per week). Immediate specialized eating disorder treatment with potential consideration of higher levels of care including intensive outpatient or inpatient treatment.

references: American Psychiatric Association. Diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders: DSM-5. 5th ed. Washington, DC: American Psychiatric Association; 2013.
Grilo CM, Ivezaj V, White MA. Evaluation of the DSM-5 severity indicator for binge eating disorder in a clinical sample. Behav Res Ther. 2015;71:110-4. doi: 10.1016/j.brat.2015.05.003.
Wonderlich SA, Gordon KH, Mitchell JE, et al. The validity and clinical utility of binge eating disorder. Int J Eat Disord. 2009;42(8):687-705. doi: 10.1002/eat.20719.
formula: Diagnostic evaluation based on DSM-5 criteria: (A) Recurrent binge eating episodes, (B) ≥3 associated features, (C) Marked distress, (D) ≥1 episode/week for 3 months, (E) No compensatory behaviors and not exclusively during other eating disorders. Severity based on episode frequency per week.
notes: This is a diagnostic tool, not a screening instrument. Clinical judgment is essential.
Weight or appearance is NOT part of the diagnostic criteria for binge eating disorder.
All core criteria (A-E) must be met for diagnosis; severity is determined by episode frequency.
Requires at least 3 of the 5 associated features in criterion B.
Distinguished from bulimia nervosa by absence of compensatory behaviors.
Consider medical complications of binge eating and associated psychiatric comorbidities.
Comprehensive clinical evaluation by qualified mental health professional is recommended.
